description.narrative: This output refers to the CARE ECRAS project under the ZRBF project, which is part of the consortia.
seat of a first-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased. # of national and sub-national assessments that inform development planning and programming, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men # of knowledge products at national and subnational levels that inform resilience planning and programming # of community projects that utilize evidence for improved resilience.
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities improved via ZRBF investments # of women and men supported by ZRBF funded programmes to cope with the effects of climate change disaggregated by type of investment # of at risk communities (wards) with a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan Percentage of farmers who used financial services (savings, agricultural credit, and/or agricultural insurance) in the past 12 months # of communities with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively Number of women and men receiving trainings in the ZRBF programme (disaggregated by training type) Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation) Percentage of farmers who practiced the value chain activities promoted by the project in the past 12 months (f/m disaggregation) Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation -head of household) supported by ZRBF # of functional small scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type)
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
- Crisis modifiers designed and built int

comment.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: Effective evidence based institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place at national and sub-national levels for increased resilience
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved via ZRBF investments.
- Unknown (baseline will be done as part of the project)
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
N/A because in the year 2020 covered all the seven consortia and hence the targets and results were all reported under the consolidated output 3.
N/A because in the year 2020 covered all the seven consortia and hence the targets and results were all reported under the consolidated output 3.

ZRBF Year runs July to June Output 1:Building evidence to improve the policy environment and stimulate service provision to enhance household and community resilience 1.1 Number of risk assessments conducted, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men. Target: 3 1.2 Number of hazards mappings developed and/or updated at subnational levels Target: 9 1.3 Robust participatory monitoring, evaluation & Learning strategic framework is established, updated and operationalized Target: Successful implementation of MEL related annual/quarterly work plans deliverables that have been approved by SC 1.4 Number of policies, or strategies that were informed by ZRBF Evidence and Learning. Target: New indicator and therefore, will set targets starting from 2020. 1.5 Number of national and sub-national DRM or development plans developed, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis. Target: 2
Output 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change Target: 653,980 people
2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation Target: 54 wards 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months Target: 25% 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively Target: 150 wards 2.5 Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation) Target: 75% 2.6 Percentage of people who practiced the value chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project in the past 12 months Target: 25% 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF Target: 6,000 2.8 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type). Target: 400
Output 3: A crisis modifier that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas in place for the Fund 3.1 Crisis modifier designed, updated and operationalized into the ZRBF programme Target: Successful implementation of CMM related annual/quarterly work plans deliverables that have been approved by SC. The Activation and implementation of the crisis modifier adhered to SOP. 3.2 Proportion of ZRBF programme participants who are deemed food insecure at the peak lean season compared to the district population Target: 30% 3.3 Average utilization score perceived by ZRBF stakeholders who used HFMS to inform early action Target: New indicator to be measured starting 2020. 3.4 Number of districts with timely and complete reporting High Frequency Monitoring data Target: 15

Output 1:Building evidence to improve the policy environment and stimulate service provision to enhance household and community resilience 1.1 Number of risk assessments conducted, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men.- 5 national risk assessments were conducted with both financial and technical assistants from ZRBF namely; ZimVAC rural assessment, ZimVAC rural IPC analysis, First round Crop and Livestock assessment, Second Round Crop and Livestock Assessment and Poverty analysis report. 1.2 Number of hazards mappings developed and/or updated at subnational levels - A total of 10 multi-hazard mappings at subnational level were produced. These were updated from the 2015 national hazard mappings to inform the current resilience building programming. 1.3 Robust participatory monitoring, evaluation & Learning strategic framework is established, updated and operationalized -Met expectation: ZRBF Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning strategic framework harmonization and MEL reflections with all consortia partners have been conducted. This includes updating of ZRBF Theory of Change (TOC), Log frame and Performance Indicator Reference Guide. -Four (4) Quarterly MEL Community of practise meetings were conducted with consortia partners to trouble shoot arising MEL issues. -A total of 12 quarterly internal performance monitoring field missions were conducted as part of HACT to all the consortia partners. Furthermore, two planned joint steering committee missions were conducted for ZVA and ECRIMS project sites. -Quarterly consortia, development partners and steering committee performance review meetings have been successfully concluded. -Quarterly performance reporting produced and approved by the SC. -ZRBF PMU conducted the Outcome Monitoring Survey for the 7 consortia under ZRBF and results were used to report the top line outcome indicators. 1.4 Number of policies, or strategies that were informed by ZRBF Evidence and Learning. - New indicator to be measured starting 2020. 1.5 Number of national and sub-national DRM or development plans developed, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis.- A total of 3 district DRM plans were produced for Insiza, Lupane and Matobo, informed by risk assessments and other evidence generated by ZRBF and taking into account gender-differentiated risk analysis.
Output 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change - 750,056 people: 311,152 males and 438,904 females, were reached during the period under review through direct project support to 141,520 households 82,812 female headed and 58,708 male headed households. Disaggregated results by investment type: Livestock Production-82,558 Crop production -174,927 Community Financial Services- 82,124 Disaster Risk Management -155,592 Demonstration Centres-10934 Non-Timber Forest Products-22,980 Mechanisation- 720 Market Linkages & Value Chains-35,900 ICT & Communication-69594 Infrastructure-102,025 Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH)-20257 Trainings-80,992 2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation - 63 wards managed to develop DRM or development plan that integrates DRM and adaptation during the period under review. 76 wards plan and 3 districts plans were updated during the reporting period 2.3 Percentage of people who used financial services (savings, credit, and/or insurance) in the past 12 months - Overall, 33.65% (Males 31.6% and Females 35.7%) of ZRBF beneficiaries used financial services during the reporting period with 33.2% being youths aged 15-34 years and 34.2% being aged 35 plus. This indicator performed well given the macro and micro economic situation presenting in the country. With the multi-faceted approaches employed in the ZRBF initiative, The highest percentage was reported by ECRAS consortium (64 percent) with the lowest percentage with e ZVA consortium (21 percent) beneficiaries. However, comparing with the set target the consortia did well in achieving this indicator. Other consortia partners had 51% ECRIMS, 47% PROGRESS, 38% BRACT, 24% MELANA and 24% SIZIMELE. 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively - 184 wards 2.5 Proportion of households adopting climate smart agricultural production technologies (f/m disaggregation) - Overall, 79.9% of ZRBF targeted households were practicing at least climate smart agricultural production technologies during the reporting period. Of which 79.2% were males and 79.7% females and 73.4% were youths aged 15-34 while 81.3% aged 35 plus. The highest percentage was found among the ECRAS consortium (97 percent) and the lowest percentage was found among the ZVA consortium (58 percent) beneficiaries. Other consortia partners had 92% ECRIMS, 89% PROGRESS, 77% BRACT, 76% MELANA and 83% SIZIMELE. 2.6 Percentage of people who practiced the value chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project in the past 12 months - Substantially exceeded expectation A total of 58.5% were found to be practising at least one value chains activity (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project during the reporting period. Disaggregation by gender shows that 59.1% were males and 58.1% were females. The youths (15-34 years old) were 58.4% while 67.7% were aged 35 plus. Further analysis revealed that 26.5% were practising three and more value chain activities (on-farm & off-farm) promoted by the project. Disaggregation by consortia; BRACT, 46.0%; ECRAS, 91%; ECRIMS, 76; MELANA, 57.4%; PROGRESS 62.1%; SIZIMELE, 62.1% and ZVA, 35.8% 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation by head of household) supported by ZRBF - 6465 households were supported through the main project. SIZIMELE- 788, ECRAS-1940, PROGRESS 759, ZVA 1580, MELANA- 1398 and an additional of 3005 households were supported via Crisis Modifier. 2.8 Number of functional small-scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support (disaggregated by type). - 428 productive infrastructures were constructed under the main project (SIZIMELE 5, MELANA 4, BRACT 202, ECRIMS 71, ZVA 26, PROGRESS 21 and ECRAS 99) 151 Boreholes have been constructed under crisis modifier (ECRIMS 24, ECRAS 18, ZVA 22, BRACT 12 and PROGRESS 75)
Output 3: A crisis modifier that can provide early warning, early action in ZRBF programme areas in place for the Fund 3.1 Crisis modifier designed, updated and operationalized into the ZRBF programme - The Crisis Modifier Mechanism Review –a formal review of ZRBF’s use of the crisis modifier mechanism has been conducted as planned. The overall objective of the Crisis Modifier Mechanism Review was to broaden ZRBF’s understanding of the adequacy of the CMM design, implementation context, gather perceptions about the efficiency, the scope and effectiveness of the Crisis Modifier interventions in safeguarding longer-term resilience gains, and document challenges faced in designing and implementing the Crisis Modifier activities. CM has been successfully activated and implemented in line with the SoP during the reporting period. 3.2 Proportion of ZRBF programme participants who are deemed food insecure at the peak lean season compared to the district population - New indicator to be measured starting 2020 3.3 Average utilization score perceived by ZRBF stakeholders who used HFMS to inform early action - New indicator to be measured starting 2020. 3.4 Number of districts with timely and complete reporting High Frequency Monitoring data - 15 districts under ZRBF programming produced complete and timely HFM data

Output 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved Output Indicator 2.1 Number of women and men supported by ZRBF funded programmes to cope with the effects of climate change disaggregated by type of investment Output Indicator 2.2 Number of communities (wards) with a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan Output Indicator 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation (f/m disaggregation -head of household) supported by ZRBF

Output 2: Absorptive, adaptive and transformative capacities of target communities improved 2.1: 224366 women and men were supported by ZRBF funded programmes to cope with the effects 2.2: 29 (wards) with a disaster risk reduction (DRR) and/or integrated disaster reduction and adaptation in their strategy or action plan 2.7: 13171 households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation

2.1 Number of people supported by ZRBF to cope with the effects of climate change. Target: 25483 2.2 Number of wards with an up-to-date DRM or development plan that integrates DRR and adaptation. Target: 29 wards 2.4 Number of wards with disaster early warning and response (EWR) systems working effectively. Target:29 wards 2.5 Number of people receiving trainings in the ZRBF Programme. Target: 1670 2.7 Number of households with access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation supported by ZRBF. Target: 270 households 2.8 Number of functional small scale productive infrastructures developed through ZRBF support. Target: 29
